comment.author: 69679868@N03
comment._content: Indistinct though it is, the cap badge is almost certainly that of the DWR rather than that of the Australian Infantry.  This soldier might be Private Henry Harry Jolly of the Duke of Wellington's Regiment, died 20 Sep 1917?//

comment.author: 69679868@N03
comment._content: Private Henry Harry Jolly, (Duke of Wellington's Regiment), if this is him, is recorded as born in Hong Kong and on enlistment received the Service Number 235396.//

comment.author: 62508825@N00
comment._content: Can't see how the photos submitted for posterity to IWM 1917-1920 can be of anyone other than the name, regiment ascribed to them. Assuming this individual enlisted as Private Robert Jolly, 17 Infantry Battalion (May 1915), reported missing on 3 May 1917: The 17th Infantry fought at 'second Bullecourt' 3-4 May 1917 www.awm.gov.au/units/unit_11204.asp The Second Battle of Bullecourt lasted from 3-15 May 1917. www.ww1westernfront.gov.au/battlefields/bullecourt-may-19... Photos here www.ww1westernfront.gov.au/bullecourt/index.html Full name Corporal Robert Waugh Jolly, born Falkirk, Scotland, age 35 at death AIF record www.aif.adfa.edu.au:8080/showPerson?pid=156536 Regimental number 591 Place of birth Persia Row, Bainsford, Falkirk School Bainsford School, Falkirk Other training Clerk Age on arrival in Australia 29 Religion Church of England Occupation Fitter Address Mercheston Place, Bamsford Falkirk, Scotland Marital status Single Age at embarkation 33 Next of kin Mother, Mrs Margaret Jolly, Mercheston Place, Bamsford Falkirk, Scotland Enlistment date 27 February 1916 Rank on enlistment Private Unit name17th Battalion, B Company AWM Embarkation Roll number23/34/1 Embarkation details Unit embarked from Sydney, New South Wales, on board HMAT A32 Themistocles on 12 May 1915 Rank from Nominal Roll Corporal Unit from Nominal Roll 17th Battalion Other details from Roll of Honour Circular Given name on RoHc Robert Waugh. FateKilled in Action 3 May 1917 Place of death or woundingBullecourt, France Age at death 35 Place of burial No known grave Commemoration details Australian National Memorial, Villers-Bretonneux, France Villers-Bretonneux is a village about 15 km east of Amiens. The Memorial stands on the high ground ('Hill 104') behind the Villers-Bretonneux Military Cemetery, Fouilloy, which is about 2 km north of Villers-Bretonneux on the east side of the road to Fouilloy. The Australian National Memorial, Villers-Bretonneux is approached through the Military Cemetery, at the end of which is an open grass lawn which leads into a three-sided court. The two pavilions on the left and right are linked by the north and south walls to the back (east) wall, from which rises the focal point of the Memorial, a 105 foot tall tower, of fine ashlar. A staircase leads to an observation platform, 64 feet above the ground, from which further staircases lead to an observation room. This room contains a circular stone tablet with bronze pointers indicating the Somme villages whose names have become synonymous with battles of the Great War; other battle fields in France and Belgium in which Australians fought; and far beyond, Gallipoli and Canberra. On the three walls, which are faced with Portland stone, are the names of 10,885 Australians who were killed in France and who have no known grave. The 'blocking course' above them bears the names of the Australian Battle Honours. After the war an appeal in Australia raised £22,700, of which £12,500 came from Victorian school children, with the request that the majority of the funds be used to build a new school in Villers-Bretonneux. The boys' school opened in May 1927, and contains an inscription stating that the school was the gift of Victorian schoolchildren, twelve hundred of whose fathers are buried in the Villers-Bretonneux cemetery, with the names of many more recorded on the Memorial. Villers-Bretonneux is now twinned with Robinvale, Victoria, which has in its main square a memorial to the links between the two towns.

comment.author: 69679868@N03
comment._content: Mistakes are sometimes made as I believe is the case with the first name here.  Further investigation reveals that this photograph was originally catalogued at the IWM in their Bond of Sacrifice Classified Collection as HU96646:  ascribed, as shown, to be Private Jolly, Robert; Duke of Wellington's Regiment.  There can be little doubt that he is wearing the cap badge of the Duke of Wellington's Regiment (The West Riding) of a 'lion rampant carrying a banner unfurled within a crown' as opposed to the 'rising sun' of the AIF.  It is possible of course, that for some reason Henry Harry Jolly was actually known as 'Robert' or 'Bob' - a nickname perhaps, or allusion to a sportsman or well known (then) Yorkshireman.  Added to which the soldier in the photograph appears to be aged between 19 and 24 - rather than 33-35//
